description: At C2, the choice between subjunctive and indicative is often pragmatic rather than grammatical. Quizás viene (I think he's coming - more certain) vs Quizás venga (he might come - less certain). Siento que no puedes venir (I'm sorry you can't come - empathizing with fact) vs Siento que no puedas venir (I'm sorry, I hope you might still come).
common_errors: Applying subjunctive rules mechanically without considering pragmatic nuance
Not recognizing that both moods can be grammatically correct with different meanings
practice_patterns: Siento que no ___ (poder) venir. (fact vs wish)
Aunque ___ (tener) razón, no estoy de acuerdo. (fact vs concession)

description: Using present tense to narrate past events for dramatic effect: Colón llega a América en 1492. Mixing narrative tenses: imperfect for background, preterite for events, present for dramatic moments, pluperfect for flashbacks. Literary use of simple past (pretérito anterior): Cuando hubo terminado, se fue.
common_errors: Inconsistent tense shifting within narrative
Overusing historical present (loses effect if constant)
practice_patterns: Era de noche. De pronto, alguien ___ (llamar) a la puerta. (narrative present)

description: Independent subjunctive for wishes, curses, and blessings: Que Dios te bendiga. Maldito sea. Así sea. Viva la libertad. Que en paz descanse. Quién pudiera (If only I could). Pluguiera a Dios (Would to God - literary). These represent the subjunctive's oldest function.
common_errors: Not recognizing these as independent subjunctive clauses
Using indicative in exclamatory wishes

concept: Stylistic inversion and marked word order
description: Literary/formal inversions: Dijo el profesor (said the professor), Bien lo sabe él (He knows it well), Grande fue su sorpresa (Great was his surprise). After negative adverbs: Nunca había visto tal cosa, Jamás lo haría. Conditional inversion: Hubiera yo sabido (Had I known). These mark register and emphasis.
common_errors: Using marked inversion in casual speech (sounds pretentious)
Not recognizing inversion patterns in literary texts

description: Advanced nominalization: el que/la que + subjunctive (whoever), lo de + infinitive/noun (the matter of), el hecho de que + subjunctive. Abstract lo: lo poco que sé, lo mucho que te quiero. Nominalized adjectives: los de abajo (those below/the underprivileged), los demás (the rest/others).
common_errors: Confusion between el que (the one who) and lo que (what/that which)
Not using lo for abstract qualities with adjectives
practice_patterns: No sabes ___ mucho que te echo de menos. (lo/el)

description: Rhetorical questions: ¿Acaso no lo sabías? (Didn't you know?). ¿Qué más da? (What does it matter?). ¿A quién le importa? Litotes for understatement: No es mala idea (= It's a good idea). Irony markers: Como si yo fuera tonto. No faltaba más (sarcastic). Digo yo (I would say - hedging).
common_errors: Taking rhetorical questions literally
Not recognizing litotes as a common Spanish understatement strategy

description: Aspectual se adds completeness/totality: comer (eat) vs comerse (eat up entirely), beber vs beberse, leer vs leerse. Middle se: the subject is affected by the process: romperse (break by itself), caerse (fall down), morirse (die - more emotional). Se me olvidó vs Olvidé (de-agentivizing).
common_errors: Not distinguishing aspectual se from reflexive se
Overusing or underusing aspectual se (it implies entirety)
practice_patterns: El vaso se ___ (caer) de la mesa. (middle voice)

concept: Conditional and imperfect for politeness and hedging
description: Softening with imperfect: Quería pedirte un favor (I wanted to ask - softer than quiero). Conditional: ¿Podrías ayudarme? Yo diría que... (I would say...). Future for softening: Será mejor que... (It would be better). Imperfect subjunctive for maximum deference: Quisiera saber si... (I would like to know).
common_errors: Using present tense for requests in formal situations
Not recognizing the politeness hierarchy: present < imperfect < conditional < imperfect subjunctive
practice_patterns: Yo ___ (decir) que no es buena idea. (diría)

description: Evidentiality: Al parecer/por lo visto (apparently), según dicen (as they say), se rumorea que (it's rumored). Hedging: digamos (let's say), por así decirlo (so to speak), en cierto modo (in a way). Reformulation: mejor dicho (rather), bueno (well), vamos (I mean). Attitude: desde luego, por supuesto, ni mucho menos.
common_errors: Not using enough discourse markers (makes speech sound flat)
Overusing the same markers repeatedly
practice_patterns: ___, no es exactamente lo que esperaba. (bueno/digamos)
___, todo salió bien. (por lo visto/según dicen)
No es, ___, una solución perfecta. (digamos/por así decirlo)

description: Mixed counterfactuals: Si hubiera estudiado, ahora sabría (past cause, present result). De no haber sido por ti, habría fracasado. Yo que tú, no lo haría (If I were you). De haber podido, habría ido. Multiple layers: Si hubiera sabido que ibas a venir, habría preparado algo que te hubiera gustado.
common_errors: Not handling multiple temporal layers correctly
Oversimplifying complex counterfactual chains
practice_patterns: Si ___ ___ (haber/estudiar) más, ahora ___ (tener) un mejor trabajo. (mixed)

concept: Grammatical metaphor and nominalizations in academic discourse
description: Turning processes into things (nominalization) for academic/formal writing: 'The company produced more' -> 'The increase in production' (el aumento de la producción). Dense nominal groups: La constante disminución del rendimiento académico de los estudiantes. Passivization and impersonalization as distancing strategies.
common_errors: Overusing nominalizations (makes text impenetrable)
Not using enough in academic writing (sounds too informal)
practice_patterns: Los precios subieron -> ___ de los precios. (la subida)
Se decidió que -> ___ fue que... (la decisión)
Los trabajadores protestaron -> ___ de los trabajadores... (la protesta)

concept: Diachronic awareness - archaic forms in modern use
description: Remnant archaic forms still in use: pluguiera/pluguiese (would it please - literary), hubiere (future subjunctive in legal texts), pretérito anterior (hubo terminado - very rare). Understanding voseo (vos + modified conjugations) in Argentine/Central American Spanish. Recognizing Ladino and historical Spanish features.
common_errors: Not recognizing archaic forms in legal or literary contexts
Confusing voseo verb forms with errors

description: Understanding implied meaning beyond literal grammar: '¿No tendrás un bolígrafo?' (polite request via negative question + future of probability). 'Si tú lo dices...' (skepticism). 'Ya veremos' (polite refusal). 'Hombre, no sé...' (hedging disagreement). Grammatical structures chosen for pragmatic effect.
common_errors: Taking pragmatic expressions at face value
Not recognizing implicit refusals, suggestions, or criticisms

concept: Subjunctive optionality zones - regional and stylistic variation
description: Zones where subjunctive/indicative varies by region: después de que (Latin America often indicative, Spain subjunctive). Quizás/Tal vez (subjunctive more common in Spain). Mientras (indicative in some Latin American varieties for 'as long as'). Colloquial indicative replacing subjunctive in subordinate clauses: Quiero que vienes (non-standard but heard).
common_errors: Assuming one dialect's usage is 'correct' and others are 'wrong'
Not adapting to the variety of Spanish being used/studied
practice_patterns: Después de que ___ (llegar). (llegue in Spain, llegó in some LA varieties)
Quizás ___ (venir) mañana. (venga or viene - both valid)
Mientras ___ (poder), seguiré trabajando. (pueda in Spain, puedo in some LA)

description: Academic: passive se, nominalization, hedging (parece que, cabe señalar), impersonal structures. Legal: future subjunctive, formal imperatives, archaic vocabulary. Journalistic: historical present, indirect speech, quotation frames. Literary: free indirect speech, stream of consciousness, tense mixing for effect.
common_errors: Using colloquial grammar in academic writing
Using overly formal grammar in creative writing
practice_patterns: (Literary) Llovía. Ella no ___ (saber) qué hacer. ___ (Abrir) la puerta y ___ (salir). (free indirect)
